question.title: Jakarta Validation - manually setting a paramName for a constraint
question.body:
Having a simple form like this:

<form action="form/bean" method="POST">
    <label for="someDate">Person's date of birth:</label>
    <input type="date" name="someDate"/><p/>
    <input type="submit" value="Submit"/>
</form>

I want to server-side validate submitted data using the following bean:

@Getter @Setter //from Lombok
public class FormData {
    @NotBlank
    @FormParam("someDate")
    @MvcBinding
    private String birthdayAsString;
    
    @MvcBinding
    @Past
    public LocalDate getBirthday(){
        try {
            return LocalDate.parse(birthdayAsString);
        }
        catch (DateTimeParseException ex){
            return null;
        }
    }
}

the validation is performed on a resource method like this:

// this is a part of a controller class that process a GET and multiple POST requests
@Inject private BindingResult bindingResult;
@POST
@Path("bean")
public void postData(@Valid @BeanParam FormData form){
    for(ParamError error : bindingResult.getAllErrors() )
    {
        System.out.println(error.getParamName()+":"+error.getMessage());
    }
    System.out.println(form);
}

the problem occurs when I submit a form with a present or future date. In such case I get a warning:

WARNING: Cannot resolve paramName for violation: ConstraintViolationImpl{interpolatedMessage='must be a past date', propertyPath=postData.arg0.birthday, rootBeanClass=x.y.z.FormController$Proxy$_$$_WeldSubclass, messageTemplate='{jakarta.validation.constraints.Past.message}'}

This warning manifests itself in logs when I try to print validation errors using error.getParamName(). For birthdayAsString I get a proper message someDate: must not be blank (if it actually is blank) but for birthday I get null:must be a past date.

How can I set the paramName for my constraint so that if this constraint is violated I will be able to trace it back to the parameter (by its name rather than null)?

answers.body:
Hi this is because you use the annotation ' @Past ' in your get birthday method.

@MvcBinding
    @Past
    public LocalDate getBirthday(){
        try {
            return LocalDate.parse(birthdayAsString);
        }
        catch (DateTimeParseException ex){
            return null;
        }
    }

if you want any date(past,present or future) support Remove the @Past annotation. If you want Today and any date before Todat you need to use @PastOrPresent annotaion or If you require furute date yo have to use @Future annotation.

and you are trying to input present or future date. So correct your annotation as per your need to get rid of this warning . You can use BindingResult for your form submission if you are using Spring MVC to get the field specific errors.

79748612.body: You can use any other annotation from jakarta.validation.constraints package and the warning will be the same. For example, if you switch @Past for @NotNull and leave the date blank you will get the same warning. The point is that whenever you trigger the constraint violation you get a message that lacks the parameter name.
